div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, For the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus | #2628 Petitioners' reply to the Government's Additional Authorities

The most striking distinction in the case of Sinis Calchi v. Thomas, 195 Fed. 710 701, cited by counsel as additional authority, which indeed is applicable to all the other cases cited, and especially to all the cases city by Judge Dodge in the California case of Jen Yuen v. United States, 186 Fed. 350, is that in them all the aliens had either been convicted, or had plead guilty, or had declined to answer in charges of claim crimes amounting to moral turpitude. Of course, in such cases, it was not necessary for the Government to go further in evidence. But that is not the case now before the Court. The petitioners herein not only have strongly denied, and still deny their guilt as charged, but have twice been tried and acquitted. Hence, we urge that under these circumstances, it is necesary for the Government to submit some proof upon which to base a Warrant for Deportation.

Judge Dodge, in the case above cited says: "The aliens' opportunity to be head need not be on any regular set occasion, nor according to the forms of judicial procedure; it may be such as will secure the prompt, vigorous action contemplated by Congress, and appropriate to the nature of the case."
This decision of Judge Dodge is perhaps the strongest and most sweeping of them all, and yet, he holds that it is necessary to have some sort of hearing upon the charge.

In the Sinis Calchi case above cited, the Court refers to the Japanese case in 189 U.S. page 87, in reference to the charges upon which the aliens were tried, and says: "It was in effected treated as immaterial, because appellant had notice of the purpose of the investigation."

Our contention in the case at bar is that the aliens did not have notice of the charge that they had assisted a prostitute in any other manner than to avoid arrest. We contend that this point was never raised until after the hearing, and for the first time in the hearing on Habeas Corpus.

With respect to the aliens' constitutional and common-ordinary rights for a hearing, we would especially commend to the Court the powerful argument of Judge Brewer in his dissenting opinion in the case of Fou Yue Tin vs. United States, 149 U.S. 698; 13 Sup. Ct. 1016; 37 L. Ed. 905. The aliens in that case had live long in the United States, had established residence and acquired property, and were being deported in much the same arbittrary manner as in this case.

We also commend to the Court the argument in the case of Yamataya vs. Fisher, 189 U.S. 86 (47 Law Ed. 721) in which the Court says: "This court has never heeld, nor must we now be understood as holding that executive officers, when executing the provisions of a statute involving the liberty of persons may disregard the fundamental priniciples that inhere in due process of law .... It is not competent for ..... any executive office .... arbitrarily to cause an alien to be deported without giving him all opportunity to be heard upon 2
the questions involving his right to be and remain in the United States. No such arbitrary power can exist where the principles involved in due process of law are recognized."
div1.ab: Respectfull submitted, R.W. McClelland Myers & Johnstone Attorneys for Petitioners
div1.p: True copies of the opening and closing brief of the Government in the above submitted cause is hereby acknowledge on this Feb 5/14
div1.ab: RW McClelland and Myers &Johnstone Attys for Petitioners
div1.p: Same acknowledgement is hereby made as to petitioners 2 give for G.P. Fishburne Assistant Dist atty
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Petitioners' reply to Government's Additional Authorities
R.W. McClellan, H.A.P. Myers W. L. Johnstone Attorney for Petitioners 1158 Empire Building
Service of within reply brief and receipt of copy admitted this 5th day of Feb. 1914 Attorney for U.S.
